X would guess that if any of these speakers mentioned Karl Harx

Di Vittorio's labor union could not really work for full employment and high
wages under Italy's present democratic system. For if those things were
aohieved under a democratic system the extreme doctrine of communism could
make little headway. Pietro Secohia and his chief lieutenant, Longo, really
want only one things power. And they surely would know what to do with it
if they got it — and they would do it ruthlessly, with no concern for
Italian workers or Italian institutions or anything else.
We know these things — but the Italians who follow Togliatti and
Secohia and Di Vittorio and Longo do not know them. And we had better
realize once and for all that these Italian workers will never take our word
for these things. They will have to find out for themselves. And tKere is
a real longrange chance in Italy that by the time they do find out it will
be too late.
The Italian working man is unquestionably much like his counter¬
part in any free country, including the United States. On a day-to-day
basis he is mostly concerned about his Job; how secure it is; how much it
pays him and enables him to do for his family. 3o far as he knows, Di
Vittorio s COIL has worked harder to provide better and more secure Jobs and
higher pay than any other agency or group. If wages and salaries are con¬
siderably higher now than they were under fascism, the worker is apt to give
credit to the COIL.
one unpleasant incident on the Italian industrial scone this last
autumn was the laying off of 2,000 steel workers in the city of Temi, north
of Rome. The Temi plant was not competitive. It had to lay off surplus
workers.
This Temi story was treated by the Communist oress as one of the
biggest news stories in Italy. When virtually all Italian dailies were de¬
voting most of their front pages and their editorials to the subject of
Trieste, the Communist newspapers were screaming Just as hard about the
Temi 2,000.
I should not want to suggest that the other newspapers ignored the
Temi situation or that the Italian government was calloused about it. But
the Communists made the loudest and most consistent noise. And X would
guess that many embittered unemployed steel workers in Temi got exactly the
idea the Communists intended them to get; that the Communists and the labor
union they dominate were the only groups that really cared very much.
